awd_abstract_narration:
This project will generate new fundamental geographic understanding of the spatial extent of sociocultural influences on populations and the degree to which specific groups or individuals assume leadership in public participation.  The project will address the complex factors that influence the public participation of different segments of a population by considering the degree to which family, education, religion, social, and other networks influence activity in public participation.  Divergent sociocultural influences will be correlated with the development of beliefs and behaviors that lead to differential leadership in public participation.  This research will provide insights regarding the diversity among groups related to their public participation rather than analyzing all people as a single category.  Results from this project will have policy implications and inform national security interests regarding emerging participation patterns and the motivation for groups that are engaged in public participation.  This multilayered examination of competing influences and changing social roles will advance existing analytic frameworks for evaluating and adopting the most effective means of ensuring security and stability in communities.  A post-doctoral fellow and a graduate student will be trained as part of the project, thereby enhancing U.S. scientific resource capacity.

The research design for this project will examine the differential use of public space across a spectrum of perspectives and social positions.  Specifically, this project will focus on the complex dynamics through which women have evolved as leaders in their families and communities.  The project will seek answers to two major research questions: (1) What are the social, economic, and other influences or drivers that compel women to participate in different types of organizations? (2) How do female leaders influence public participation and ensure security within their families and communities?  The investigators will use multi-sited qualitative analysis of participation in organizations across different regional locations, ethnicities, socioeconomic class levels, educational experiences, and scales of influence.  Data-collection methods will include interviews, focus groups, and content analysis of data from printed sources and documents.  This project will focus on Afghanistan, a nation that has been of considerable interest to the United States from a national security perspective, and it will provide insights and approaches for considering public participation across different groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The data collected and analyzed for this project resulted in five major findings: 1) The extent of Afghan women?s authority and influence; 2) the importance of legitimacy and security for effective gender-based programming; 3) the diversity of women?s lives and experiences and inability of most international organizations to incorporate this into their projects/programs; 4) women?s influence at the family and community scale; 5) lack of sustainable programs and dependence of international assistance along with the resurgence of the Taliban.

 

First, Afghan women?s authority and influence varies significantly by spatial location and situational influences. A woman?s natal family, prior to marriage, and spouse?s family after marriage remain the primary influence and arbiter of women?s lives. Familia influence is mitigated by several other influences that are geographically specific. A women?s ability to participate in educational opportunities, largely funded by international assistance, relied on the accessibility of schools in a particular location and permission from a woman?s family to access a school if available. Family permissions were influenced by several factors including safety/security, type of curriculum, belief in educating girls/women, and thoughts or pressure from family and community leaders/elders. Women?s leadership and authority also varied by scale. Women in leadership positions at the national scale were ensured through a quota system. However, women?s influence within government and the reach of their authority beyond the capital city was limited. The authority and influence of Afghan women-led and focused nongovernmental and civil society organizations (NGOs/CSOs) were largely vested in the existing networks associated with the leadership of these organizations. Thus, women?s influence relies heavily on familial networks and collaborations with other organizations with an established reputation within a given community.

 

Second, establishing and maintaining legitimacy within a community was of utmost importance for women?s NGOs/CSOs. This legitimacy required providing programing that did not radically alter existing gender roles/relations, long-term projects with identifiably positive results, and remaining in good standing with local leaders. Lack of security was regularly identified as a prime reason for pausing or ending projects/programs.

 

Third, the diversity of women?s lives which are vested in several intersectional factors including geographic location, age, ethnicity, education access/level, family structure, belief systems, types of influence outside one?s family, status, and socioeconomic class. Despite this diversity most internationally funded assistance programs relied on a narrow categorization of women as a single or homogenous group rather than disparate and heterogenous. The inability of international funding agencies to attend to this extensive diversity represents a foundational flaw in the scope, scale, and reach of their projects and programs. Dismissing or misunderstanding the diversity of women?s lives led to the failure of several projects or the inability to sustain these programs due to lack of community acceptance or NGO/CSO legitimacy.

 

Fourth, women?s influence within families and communities cannot be easily quantified. Women?s influence varies qualitatively through their ability to work within the bounds of patriarchy, culture, custom, religion and other belief systems. Women?s leadership at the domestic and community scale, similar to male leadership, is predominantly vested in elder women who have proven themselves as honorable and virtuous within an Islamic context. The development of a woman?s honor and virtue includes being an obedient wife/daughter-in-law, a mother, and is further mitigated by the standing and status of her family within a given community. Women?s leadership can also be vested in her care work within the community as a respectable teacher, nurse, doctor, or midwife. Thus, women?s value remains contingent upon the gender-based roles ascribed to her and vis-?-vis her relationships with and how she is viewed by senior members of her family and community. While women?s influence and authority are highly mitigated by gender-based expectations, these expectations vary significantly based on number of factors including geographic location and access to public and political spaces along with economic and educational opportunities.

 

Fifth, Afghan women led and focused organizations? reliance on international funding from the United States and its allies has been acutely evident. This dependence was further underscored after the Taliban resurgence and US withdrawal from Afghanistan. Many women?s rights activists and well-known leaders evacuated from the country or went into hiding. Thus, many projects have ended or are significantly disrupted due to this major geopolitical shift. However, several women continue to run businesses, and home-based education is on the rise in Afghanistan. Women have been and continue to be caught between several competing power brokers seeking to influence or control women?s bodies, reproduction, mobility, work, and access to knowledge, economic opportunity, political participation, and public spaces. Improving the lives of women in Afghanistan cannot occur without a clear understanding of the complex, complicated, competing, and often contradictory expectations of women along with their diverse ideologies and methodologies for change. This is further complicated by the existence of the Taliban regime?s restrictions on women?s education, work, and mobility.
